Generation II.Gold: When the stars flicker in the night sky, it flutters about, scattering a glowing powder.
Generation II.Silver: The star patterns on its back grow larger or smaller depending on the number of stars in the night sky.
Generation II.Crystal: In the daytime when it gets warm, it curls up inside a big leaf and drifts off into a deep slumber.
Generation II.Stadium 2: When the stars flicker in the night sky, it flutters about, scattering a glowing powder. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) The star patterns on its back grow larger or smaller depending on the number of stars in the night sky. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: It is said that in lands with clean air, where the stars fill the sky, there live Ledian in countless numbers. There is a good reason for this - the Pok é mon uses the light of the stars as its energy.
Generation III.Sapphire: It is said that in lands with clean air, where the stars fill the sky, there live Ledian in countless numbers. There is a good reason for this - the Pok é mon uses the light of the stars as its energy.
Generation III.Emerald: It is said that in lands with clean air, where the stars fill the sky, there live many Ledian . For good reason, they use the light of the stars as energy.
Generation III.FireRed: The star patterns on its back grow larger or smaller depending on the number of stars in the night sky.
Generation III.LeafGreen: When the stars flicker in the night sky, it flutters about, scattering a glowing powder.

Generation IV.Diamond: It uses starlight as energy. When more stars appear at night, the patterns on its back grow larger.

Generation VI.X: When the stars flicker in the night sky, it flutters about, scattering a glowing powder.
Generation VI.Y: The spot patterns on its back grow larger or smaller depending on the number of stars in the night sky.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: It is said that in lands with clean air, where the stars fill the sky, there live Ledian in countless numbers. There is a good reason for this—the Pokémon uses the light of the stars as its energy.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: It is said that in lands with clean air, where the stars fill the sky, there live Ledian in countless numbers. There is a good reason for this—the Pokémon uses the light of the stars as its energy.

Generation VII.Sun: While it's believed that starlight provides it with energy, this Pokémon also loves to eat berries. In the daytime, it curls up in the grass to sleep.
Generation VII.Moon: In battle, it throws punches with all four arms. The power of each individual blow is piddly, so it aims to win by quantity rather than quality.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: It's said that the patterns on its back are related to the stars in the night sky, but the details of that relationship remain unclear.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: It flies through the night sky, sprinkling sparkly dust. According to some, if that dust sticks to you, good things will happen to you.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It uses starlight as energy. When more stars appear at night, the patterns on its back grow larger.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It uses starlight as energy. When more stars appear at night, the patterns on its back grow larger.
